Posts.Title: Current Tools To Identify AS Candidates Not Accurate

Posts.Content: Hi Jim 215, thanks for the suggestion. Johns Hopkins confirmed the results and also upgraded one of the 3+4 to 3+5, then added another 3+3 of less than 5%. I was diagnosed with 3+3 in August 2012, tracking PSA religiously, every three to four months at two different places to avoid false readings. One Prolaris Test, low risk of 2%. Two Oncotype DX tests, low risk. Two subsequent biopsied from first Bx showed G6s. PSA gradually rose from 3.2 to 5.3, brought that up with my uro but my uro just said PSA was not the best indication. Last Bx on 05/05/2017, one G9, one G8, one G7, two G6s. I think the first three biopsied missed the G9, genomic tests gave me false sense of security, they are only as good as the samples tested. All biopsies were T3MRI fused, two at USC and two at UCLA. MRI never picked up this G9 or G8 spots. I thought that the 3TMRI would pick up aggressive type of PCa but apparently not. The G9 spot was from the systematic 12 samples not from the targeted spots pointed by the MRI.

Posts.Content: I am a bit surprised that 62 is considered too young for AS! I was diagnosed in Aug 2012 at 60 with 3 out of 14 cores at G6 (5% to 20%). I had another Bx (3TprMRI - color Doppler fused Bx) at 18 months and found 1 out of 15 at G6. I also had a Prolaris test which showed low risk of 2% of PCa specific mortality rate in 10 years. I am not saying that this is the right decision for everybody, you may want to use every tool available to help you make a treatment decision. Prolaris test is one of the tools. Perhaps PHI is another test to help determine if your PCa is aggressive or not.

Posts.Content: Have you ever looked into Focal Laser Ablation? There is a thread on inspire.com with mor than 2000 posts on it, two doctors specializing in the procedure also participated. Google focal "laser ablation patients inspire.com", start by reading the first few pages and then may be go to the last page and read it backward. Dr. Walter at UTMB, and Dr. Sperling are the two participating. There is also a spreadsheet with data supplied by the patients (39) so we can track their progress. Pretty informative thread by real doctors and real patients, definitely worth reading. I am G6, diagnosed in Aug 2012 and still on AS. FLA would be one of the options, in fact, the first option I would consider, if and when I decide for a treatment. Good luck Mp

Posts.Title: Medicare covers Prolaris Genetic Test for low risk patients.

Posts.Content: MODERATOR'S NOTE: I removed the link because it could also serve as a marketing vehicle. But the main content of the article does seem to bear relevence to some cases. So I copy-pasted the body of text into akai's post so that the main message can still get through. --Chuck Myriad Matters Blog Back to Blog Medicare Covers Prolaris Genetic Test for Low-Risk Prostate Cancer Mark Capone Portrait 6.2.15 WebAugust 13, 2015 On August 13, 2015, Medicare approved coverage of the ProlarisÂ® test for men diagnosed with low-risk and very low-risk prostate cancer. The decision is the culmination of years of scientific discovery, research and collaboration, and is an enormous step in improving patient care. Every day, 630 men in the United States are diagnosed with prostate cancer, and 82 die from the disease. Daunting statistics like these underscore the tremendous need for better tools to fight this deadly cancer. We know that most prostate cancers are slow growing; however, some grow quickly. The challenge always has been telling aggressive from nonaggressive cancer. Prior to the genomics revolution, and for the last 50 years, physicians largely relied on the Gleason score, clinical grade and, after its development, PSA to evaluate the prognosis of men with prostate cancer. A Gleason score is determined based upon how cancer cells look under a microscope – the higher the score, the worse the prognosis. Although clinically useful, the Gleason score is subjective and imperfect. Fast forward to today. [part of content, with graphic, removed] Prolaris is the first prognostic test to determine the aggressiveness of prostate cancer and has been studied in more than 10 clinical studies with thousands of patients. The test measures the activity level of 46 genes and provides physicians with precise objective information that is based on the tumor’s genetic profile. Simply put, men with a low Prolaris score have a low risk of disease progression and may be candidates for active surveillance, while those with a high score are at higher risk and may benefit from additional therapy. The Prolaris test already is changing the equation in the fight against prostate cancer. Any physician who has treated prostate cancer knows all too well the personal and financial cost of undertreating an aggressive cancer or overtreating a slow growing, indolent cancer. More work needs to be done to reduce the death toll from prostate cancer, but Medicare’s positive decision will help ensure that Medicare patients who need a Prolaris test will have access. Mark Capone CEO, Myriad Genetics

Posts.Title: Feeling Cured

Posts.Content: Hi: I think you already are aware that high PSA score does not mean you have cancer. That said, 3.35 at 53 yrs old is a bit high, hopefully it was caused by the enlarged prostate. There are other tests such as PCA3 that is more cancer specific than PSA. If you are not comfortable with your Uro you should find another one. Biopsy, while extremely uncomfortable, is not that painful. You may not want to travel right after biopsy as you will see blood in your urine, stool, and semen that may freak you out. Find the best care possible, do not compromise, best of luck. Keep us posted. Ask more questions if you need to.

Posts.Content: Hi Engel9, please also investigate Focal Laser Ablation. Please google focal laser ablation patients inspire.com. There is an active thread on FLA with over 2000 posts. There are also two doctors participating, Dr. Sperling, and Dr. Walser, both specialized in FLA. The thread is quite long, over 100 pages, you can skim through them. Most interesting are the last 10 pages or so. There is also a spreadsheet created by a participant keeping track of the progress of patients. Since you do not want to consider AS, FLA is a compromise to surgery. The two doctors are probably the most experienced in FLA, you can actually contact them and discuss your case once you have more info. Dr. Walser is quite responsive to patients as well. Mp

My score was -0.1 which gives me the mortality risk of 2%. I was Dxed in 2012 with 3 out of 14 samples, all G6, second Bx showed 1 sample out of 15 at G6. Still on AS. Posts.Content: Did the Uro feel the nodule during DRE, that may rule out AS. if you have a hard time knowing you have cancer inside you then AS is definitely NOT for you. I am on AS, while I do not think about my PCa every day, it does creep in from time to time and the fear of missing the window of opportunity is not pleasant. There are several treatments out there, perhaps focal therapies (hot or cold) may work better for you. Take your time to learn about all your options before you decide. Good luck.

This is what I am doing for myself. I have done Prolaris Test which classified my PCa as not aggressive. The limitation of the Prolaris test is that the result is based on the samples provided, so if the Bx missed the higher grade PCa, then the result may be misleading.

Posts.Content: Is his Gleason score 6 or 7? If it is 6 and he is 75 years old he may want to consider Active Surveillance instead. I did look into Proton Therapy at Loma Linda but decided to stay on AS for the time being. My Gleadon score was 6. If his G score is 7, please find out if it is 4+3 or 3+4? The first digit determines the agressiveness, 4+3 is more agressive than 3+4. Even at 3+4, he may qualify for AS because of his age. Please take your time, investigate all options. At his age, surgery is out. There are plenty of options out there today. Please post as much info about his records as possible so we can help.

Posts.Content: I am G9 but no met (localized) , my MO started me with Casodex and Eligard in June, then switched from Casodex to Zytiga with Prednisone in July, still with Eligard. Initially my insurance company denied the coverage of Zytiga but my MO appealed. I am neither Castrate Resistance nor Met. Casodex + Eligard was working, my PSA went from 5.3 to 2.54, so it was working, my PSA went down 0.25 one month into Zytiga (it might have been 0.25 anyway with Casodex but will never know now). Almost two months into Zytiga, my PSA was down to 0.05 on 08/28, two days before my HDRBT. I think one of the studies concluded that a combination therapy of ADT plus Abiraterone provided overall significant survival in men with locally advanced or Metastatic prostate cancer. My MO participated in one of the two Zytiga studies. http://www.practiceupdate.com/journa...0&lid=10332481 On Wednesday I completed a single HDBRT at UCLA as a boost to IMRT which is coming up soon. My MO never mentioned that Zytiga is not safe for radiation. I will probably start IMRT in about two to three weeks. Hope this help.
